Monitoring Multiple Clusters with the Dashboard
The cluster information displayed in the Dashboard is stored in a persistent cookie. This means you need to decide which &hawk; instance you want to view the Dashboard on, and always use that one. The machine you are running &hawk; on does not even need to be part of any cluster for that purpose—it can be a separate, unrelated system.
Monitoring Multiple Clusters with &hawk;
Prerequisites
All clusters to be monitored from &hawk;'s Dashboard must be running &productname; &productnumber;. It is not possible to monitor clusters that are running earlier versions of &productname;.

Start the &hawk; Web service on a machine you want to use for monitoring multiple clusters.
Start a Web browser and as URL enter the IP address or host name of the machine that runs &hawk;: https://IPaddress:7630/
Log in to the &hawk; Web interface.
From the left navigation bar, select Dashboard.
To add dashboards for multiple clusters, click Add Cluster:
Enter a custom Cluster name with which to identify the cluster in the Dashboard.
Enter the Hostname of a node in the cluster.
To specify further options like the update interval for &hawk;, the port to connect to or if to use HTTPS (default), click Advanced and enter the details.
Confirm your changes with Add.
To add more clusters to the dashboard, click Add Cluster again and enter the details for the next cluster.
&hawk;—Dashboard
To remove a cluster from the dashboard, click the x icon next to the cluster's name.
To view details about a cluster, enter a password and click Connect.
&hawk; will show you a summary with the status of the respective cluster. taroth 2015-10-29: krig: is the following still true? From here, you can administer the cluster with &hawk; as usual.
Any status changes for nodes or resources are reflected almost immediately within the Cluster Dashboard.
Managing Tickets with &hawk;
Granting Tickets to Current Site

Though you can view tickets for all sites with &hawk;, any grant operations triggered by &hawk; only apply to the current site (that you are currently connected to with &hawk;). To grant a ticket to another site of your &geo; cluster, start &hawk; on one of the cluster nodes belonging to the respective site.

&hawk; Cluster Status (Summary View)—Ticket Details
To revoke a ticket, click the wrench icon next to the ticket and select Revoke. Confirm your choice when &hawk; prompts for a confirmation.
If the ticket cannot be revoked for any reason, &hawk; shows an error message. After the ticket has been successfully revoked, &hawk; will update the ticket status in the Tickets category.
You can only grant tickets that are not already given to any site. To grant a ticket to the current site:
Click the wrench icon next to a ticket with the current status Revoked and select Grant.
Confirm your choice when &hawk; prompts for a confirmation.
If the ticket cannot be granted for any reason, &hawk; shows an error message. After the ticket has been successfully granted, &hawk; will update the ticket status in the Tickets category.
Simulating Granting and Revoking Tickets
&hawk;'s Simulator allows you to explore failure scenarios before they happen. To explore whether your resources that depend on a certain ticket behave as expected, you can also test the impact of granting or revoking tickets.
Start a Web browser and log in to &hawk;.
Click the wrench icon next to the user name in the top-level row, and select Simulator.
&hawk;'s background changes color to indicate the simulator is active. A simulator dialog opens in the bottom right hand corner of the screen. Its title Simulator (initial state) indicates that the Cluster Status screen still reflects the current state of the cluster.
To simulate status change of a ticket:
Click +Ticket in the simulator control dialog.
Select the Action you want to simulate.
Confirm your changes to add them to the queue of events listed in the controller dialog below Injected State.
To start the simulation, click Run in the simulator control dialog. The Cluster Status screen displays the impact of the simulated events. The simulator control dialog changes to Simulator (final state).
To exit the simulation mode, close the simulator control dialog. The Cluster Status screen switches back to its normal color and displays the current cluster state.
&hawk;Simulator—Tickets
For more information about &hawk;'s Simulator (and which other scenarios can be explored with it), refer to the &haguide; for &productname;, available from . Refer to chapter Configuring and Managing Cluster Resources (Web Interface), section Exploring Potential Failure Scenarios.
